awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identity, Stereotypes and Black College Student Success
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed studies will explore, in depth, heterogeneity in the vulnerability of black college students to stereotype threat, and the way in which incentives can mitigate the impact of the threat. Stereotype threat occurs when members of a social group, in a given situation, feel themselves to be at risk of confirming a negative stereotype about their group and therefore perform less well, especially on important or difficult tasks. The study will contribute to knowledge about stereotype threat by identifying factors that contribute to or mitigate the threat and the consequences of stereotype threat vulnerability, and by developing a policy designed to combat its effects on black college students. It addresses one of the most important questions in the study of human capital investment today, which is why black students underperform and as a result are more likely to fail to complete a college degree. 

In this proposal the principal investigators plan a series of lab experimental studies that will explore the interaction between stereotype threat and two types of incentives: piece rates and prizes. The project will explore the relationship among a set of key factors that are likely to be responsible for the differences in vulnerability to stereotype threat, and carefully explore the impact of incentives and their interaction with stereotype threat. The proposal has high policy relevance because it can inform the development of interventions to enhance the performance of black students enrolled at institutions with varying demographic distributions.

por.por_cntn:
Texas A&M University (TAMU), Prairie View A&M University (PAMU) and Duke University engaged in a collaborative project to examine the impact of stereotype threat at a predominately white institution and at a historically black institution.   Stereotype threat is a phenomenon that occurs when members of a social group, in a given situation, feel themselves to be at risk of confirming a negative stereotype about their group and therefore perform less well, especially on important or difficult tasks. This phenomenon has been replicated and confirmed extensively, and is thought to be a contributing factor for the underperformance of black college students. However, little is known about individual variability in their vulnerability to stereotype threat, and what factors might mitigate the impact of the threat on college performance.

The survey was administered at TAMU and PAMU.  Duke University analyzed the data.  The requeated basic demographic information – e.g. age, gender, race, and nativity—the survey asked for the individual’s estimate of their high school GPA (we were not able to ask this question yet at TAMU), whether they expect to graduate in four years or less, whether they attended a predominantly white high school, whether they had classes that predominantly included white students in high school, and whether they were from a predominantly white neighborhood. To assess their degree of vulnerability to stereotype threat, the survey included a modified version of Elizabeth Pitel’s stigma consciousness scale (STV). To assess their degree of racial/ethnic identification, the survey included Jean S. Phinney’s Multi Group Ethnic Identity Measure (MEIM). Finally, the survey asked about a series of additional “non-cognitive” attributes of the first year student using appropriate instruments: extraversion, confidence, competitiveness, trust, neuroticism, impulsivity, conscientiousness, locus of control, and implicit theory of intelligence.

Results indicated there was no difference in the degree of stereotype threat susceptibility among black students across the two campuses (p=.5431). Keeping in mind there only were 13 white and 8 biracial participants at PVAMU, if p<.05 is taken as the standard for statistical significance, there also was no difference among white students at each of the campuses, but if p<.10 is taken as the threshold, there was a statistical difference between the non-black students on each of the campuses (p=.073). On both campuses, black students generally displayed higher STV scores than non-black students, and intra-campus differences were statistically significant for both. The gap was wider at TAMU, the predominantly white university.

In contrast, although there was no difference in the strength of ethno-racial identification between non-black students at PVAMU and TAMU, there was a significant difference between black students. Black students at PVAMU had higher MEIM scores than black students at TAMU. On both campuses, black students had significantly higher MEIM scores than non-black students although the means for non-black students were approximately 2 out a maximum value of 3. The means for black students approached 2.5.

At both schools, greater stereotype threat vulnerability was associated with higher MEIM scores for black students, suggesting that a higher the degree of racial identification goes in tandem with a higher degree of susceptibility to stigma consciousness. Female students were substantially more vulnerable than male students, although there was no statistical difference in MEIM scores. While the self-reported high school GPA at PVAMU was not related to STV, it was related negatively to MEIM.

For black students, coming from a predominantly non-white background was negatively related to STV and positively related to MEIM. Levels of neuroticism rose with higher levels of susceptibility to stereotype threat and fell with higher levels of racial-ethno identification. It also is noteworthy that neither black nor white students tended to view intelligence as malleable when we gauged their implicit theory of intelligence, regardless of STV and MEIM scores. Self-confidence was positively related to MEIM scores at both institutions, but it was negatively related to STV scores at PVAMU and positively related at TAMU, although in both cases the latter association was weak.

In addition, students with a greater degree of stereotype vulnerability were more likely to have an external locus of control. Sense of trust also fell with higher STV scores. Conscientiousness was negatively related to STV scores at PVAMU, but positively related at TAMU.

Because the surveys were administered very early in the first year students’ first semester at their respective institutions, the findings obtained reasonably can be viewed as a consequence of attitudes they held upon entry into college, rather than attitudes that evolved due to the college experience. This provides a valuable baseline for the longitudinal follow up on these students, particularly with respect to their subsequent academic performance.
